context: All people who regularly drink coffee are dependent on caffeine. People either regularly drink coffee or joke about being addicted to caffeine. No one who jokes about being addicted to caffeine is unaware that caffeine is a drug. Rina is either a student and unaware that caffeine is a drug, or neither a student nor unaware that caffeine is a drug. If Rina is not a person dependent on caffeine and a student, then Rina is either a person dependent on caffeine and a student, or neither a person dependent on caffeine nor a student.
question: Based on the above information, is the following statement true, false, or uncertain? Rina is a person who jokes about being addicted to caffeine or unaware that caffeine is a drug.
raw_logic_programs:
Predicates:
Dependent(x) ::: x is a person dependent on caffeine.
Drinks(x) ::: x regularly drinks coffee.
Jokes(x) ::: x jokes about being addicted to caffeine.
Unaware(x) ::: x is unaware that caffeine is a drug.
Student(x) ::: x is a student.

Premises:
∀x (Drinks(x) → Dependent(x)) ::: All people who regularly drink coffee are dependent on caffeine.
∀x (Drinks(x) ⊕ Jokes(x)) ::: People either regularly drink coffee or joke about being addicted to caffeine.
∀x (Jokes(x) → ¬Unaware(x)) ::: No one who jokes about being addicted to caffeine is unaware that caffeine is a drug. 
(Student(rina) ∧ Unaware(rina)) ⊕ ¬(Student(rina) ∨ Unaware(rina)) ::: Rina is either a student and unaware that caffeine is a drug, or neither a student nor unaware that caffeine is a drug. 
¬(Dependent(rina) ∧ Student(rina)) → (Dependent(rina) ∧ Student(rina)) ⊕ ¬(Dependent(rina) ∨ Student(rina)) ::: If Rina is not a person dependent on caffeine and a student, then Rina is either a person dependent on caffeine and a student, or neither a person dependent on caffeine nor a student.

Conclusion:
Jokes(rina) ∨ Unaware(rina) ::: Rina is a person who jokes about being addicted to caffeine or unaware that caffeine is a drug.<tool_call>

context: Every chef can cook. Some people who aren’t chefs can cook. People who cook can make scrambled eggs and pasta. If someone can make cookies and muffins, they are a baker. Bakers who can also make scrambled eggs can make a good breakfast. Luke can make cookies, scrambled eggs, and muffins, but not pasta.
question: Based on the above information, is the following statement true, false, or uncertain? Luke can make a good breakfast.
raw_logic_programs:
Predicates:
Chef(x) ::: x is a chef.
CanCook(x) ::: x can cook.

CanMakePasta(x) ::: x can make pasta.
CanMakeCookies(x) ::: x can make cookies.
CanMakeMuffins(x) ::: x can make muffins.
Baker(x) ::: x is a baker.
CanMakeGoodBreakfast(x) ::: x can make a good breakfast.

Premises:
∀x (Chef(x) → CanCook(x)) ::: Every chef can cook.
∃x (¬Chef(x) ∧ CanCook(x)) ::: Some people who aren’t chefs can cook.
∀x (CanCook(x) → (CanMakeScrambledEggs(x) ∧ CanMakePasta(x))) ::: People who cook can make scrambled eggs and pasta.
∀x ((CanMakeCookies(x) ∧ CanMakeMuffins(x)) → Baker(x)) ::: If someone can make cookies and muffins, they are a baker.
∀x ((Baker(x) ∧ CanMakeScrambledEggs(x)) → CanMakeGoodBreakfast(x)) ::: Bakers who can also make scrambled eggs can make a good breakfast.
CanMakeCookies(luke) ∧ CanMakeScrambledEggs(luke) ∧ CanMakeMuffins(luke) ∧ ¬CanMakePasta(luke) ::: Luke can make cookies, scrambled eggs, and muffins, but not pasta.

Conclusion:
CanMakeGoodBreakfast(luke) ::: Luke can make a good breakfast.<tool_call>

Conclusion:
Larger(eight, seven) ::: Eight is larger than seven.<tool_call>

context: No fish are birds. Everything that is an osprey is a bird. If something is a carp, then it is a fish. All goldfish are carp. If Bubbles is either an osprey or a goldfish, then Bubbles is not a fish.

raw_logic_programs:
Predicates:

Bird(x) ::: x is a bird.

Goldfish(x) ::: x is a goldfish.

Premises:

∀x (Osprey(x) → Bird(x)) ::: Everything that is an osprey is a bird.
∀x (Carp(x) → Fish(x)) ::: If something is a carp, then it is a fish.
∀x (Goldfish(x) → Carp(x)) ::: All goldfish are carp.
(Osprey(bubbles) ∨ Goldfish(bubbles)) → ¬Fish(bubbles) ::: If Bubbles is either an osprey or a goldfish, then Bubbles is not a fish.

Conclusion:
Osprey(bubbles) ::: Bubbles is an Osprey.<tool_call>

context: Mr. and Mrs. Smith make a travel plan, they want to go to a city in California or Florida, and where neither of them has ever been. raw_logic_programs:

Premises:
InState(sanFrancisco, california) ∧ InState(losAngeles, california) ∧ InState(sanDiego, california) ∧ InState(orlando, florida) ∧ InState(miami, florida) ::: Cities in California and Florida.
InterestedIn(mrSmith, sanFrancisco) ∧ InterestedIn(mrSmith, losAngeles) ∧ InterestedIn(mrSmith, sanDiego) ∧ InterestedIn(mrsSmith, sanFrancisco) ∧ InterestedIn(mrsSmith, losAngeles) ∧ InterestedIn(mrsSmith, sanDiego) ∧ InterestedIn(mrSmith, orlando) ∧ InterestedIn(mrSmith, miami) ∧ InterestedIn(mrsSmith, orlando) ∧ InterestedIn(mrsSmith, miami) ::: Cities they are interested in.
∃x ∃y (InState(x, california) ∧ BeenTo(mrSmith, x) ∧ x ≠ y ∧ InState(y, california) ∧ BeenTo(mrSmith, y)) ::: Mr. Smith has been to two cities in California.
∃z (InState(z, florida) ∧ BeenTo(mrsSmith, z)) ::: Mrs. Smith has been to one city in Florida.

Conclusion:
BeenTo(mrSmith, sanFrancisco) ::: Mr. Smith has been to San Francisco.<tool_call>

Predicates:
Provided(fruit) ::: The party provides the fruit.
SameWeightAtStart(fruit1, fruit2) ::: Fruit1 and fruit2 are provided in the same weight at the beginning of the party.

MostPopular(fruit) ::: Fruit was the most popular at the party.
LowerLeftover(fruit1, fruit2) ::: The amount of leftover fruit1 was lower than that of fruit2 at the end of the party.
Ate(person, fruit) ::: Person ate the fruit at the party.

Premises:
Provided(strawberry) ∧ Provided(orange) ∧ Provided(blueberry) ∧ Provided(grape) ∧ Provided(cherry) ::: The party provides five kinds of fruits: strawberry, orange, blueberry, grape, and cherry.
SameWeightAtStart(strawberry, orange) ∧ SameWeightAtStart(strawberry, blueberry) ∧ SameWeightAtStart(strawberry, grape) ∧ SameWeightAtStart(strawberry, cherry) ::: All fruits are provided in the same weight at the beginning of the party.

LowestRemainingWeight(strawberry) ::: Strawberries had the lowest remaining weight at the end of the party.
LowerLeftover(blueberry, cherry) ::: At the end of the party, the amount of leftover blueberries was lower than that of cherries.
Ate(benjamin, orange) ∧ Ate(benjamin, grape) ∧ ¬∃x (Ate(benjamin, x) ∧ x ≠ orange ∧ x ≠ grape) ::: Benjamin only ate oranges and grapes at the party.

Conclusion:
MostPopular(blueberry) ::: Blueberries were the most popular fruit at the party. 

Note: The conclusion does not logically follow from the premises given. According to the premises, strawberries had the lowest remaining weight and thus were the most popular fruit. Therefore, the statement "Blueberries were the most popular fruit at the party" is false based on the given information. However, the formal logic representation of the conclusion is provided as requested.<tool_call>
